title: How to Cut Baby Tomatoes

steps.headline: Dump tomatoes onto a plate.
steps.description: You want an even layer of tomatoes, no tomatoes should be on top of each other.

steps.headline: Cover the plate containing the tomatoes with another plate, topside down.
steps.description:
You should have a perfect fit so make sure the edges line up but you also have a small gap between the two plates. Don’t press downward or you may smash the tomatoes. A gentle fit will work well. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/96\/Cut-Baby-Tomatoes-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Cut-Baby-Tomatoes-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/96\/Cut-Baby-Tomatoes-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Cut-Baby-Tomatoes-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

steps.headline: Slide your knife through the plate gap, working you way through the tomatoes.
steps.description: Your top hand should hold the plate in place so the tomatoes (and plate) don’t roll around.

steps.headline: Remove plate to reveal several perfectly cut baby tomatoes!

text:
Dump tomatoes onto a plate. You want an even layer of tomatoes, no tomatoes should be on top of each other. Cover the plate containing the tomatoes with another plate, topside down. You should have a perfect fit so make sure the edges line up but you also have a small gap between the two plates. Don’t press downward or you may smash the tomatoes. A gentle fit will work well. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/96\/Cut-Baby-Tomatoes-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Cut-Baby-Tomatoes-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/96\/Cut-Baby-Tomatoes-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Cut-Baby-Tomatoes-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Slide your knife through the plate gap, working you way through the tomatoes. Your top hand should hold the plate in place so the tomatoes (and plate) don’t roll around. Remove plate to reveal several perfectly cut baby tomatoes! Finished.
